title: Iron Mountain Pitches Renewable Energy to Data-Center Customers
text:
Iron Mountain Inc. is stepping up efforts to sell data-center customers on solar, wind and other renewable-energy sources by touting benefits including lower electricity bills.

The Boston company this month opened a new data-center facility in Phoenix, powered by wind farms in Texas and across the Midwest.

With the new facility, the nearly 70-year-old document storage and information services company operates 15 data-center facilities across North America, Europe and Asia, serving roughly 1,300 customers—all running on renewable-energy sources, according to the company.

The 40-acre Phoenix site, which includes surrounding land pegged for future development, is expected to support more than 100 megawatts of IT load when complete, Iron Mountain said.

“For all the big customers, power is the biggest part of their data-center bills,” said Mark Kidd, executive vice president and general manager of Iron Mountain’s data-center operations. He said renewable sources can offer up to 30% in energy savings.

Cost and efficiency are two of the main drivers behind the push by companies to unload a good portion of their IT systems and software to third-party data centers, he said.

By renting space in these warehouse-sized facilities, equipped with racks, servers, cooling systems and other hardware, companies only pay for the amount of power they use, on top of the terms set out in rental agreements.

That can be considerable. In the U.S. alone, companies paid for a total of 171 megawatts at facilities in the country’s largest data-center rental markets, during the first six months of 2019. That is on pace for a record, according to real-estate services firm CBRE Group Inc.

Data-center operators in key U.S. markets have increased total power capacity by 200 megawatts this year, up about 8% from the same period last year, to keep up with rising demand, CBRE estimates.

Computer infrastructure, along with the internet, is on pace to use up to 15% of all the world’s electricity by 2030, emitting up to 7% of the world’s energy-related carbon emissions, according to researchers at Huawei Technologies Co.

The biggest data-center landlords, such as Equinix Inc. and Digital Realty Trust Inc., typically charge rent for physical space, equipment and security services—depending on the rental terms—while the companies pay for the power they use, based on an agreed price negotiated with local utilities.

Their largest customers are cloud-service providers, but also include other technology firms, as well as banks, retailers and any other businesses.

About 9,100 data centers world-wide are owned and operated by cloud service providers, data-center landlords and other technology firms, up from 7,500 last year, according to International Data Corp., which expects that number to top 10,000 by 2020.

Mr. Kidd said many data-center operators are simply following the lead set by big cloud-computing providers—not least market front-runner Amazon.com Inc. —in moving toward renewable energy.

Pushing local utilities to supply data-center operators with renewable sources of energy wouldn’t be possible without the large cloud companies stepping in, “because you didn’t have enough draw in any one place as a consumer of power” to make it worthwhile for energy suppliers, he said.

Amazon Web Services, the e-commerce giant’s cloud computing division, last year surpassed a goal of providing half of the power usage at its data-center facilities through renewable-energy sources, the company said.

AWS also recently announced projects to build four new wind farms and one new solar farm, including two located in the U.S., two in Ireland and one in Sweden, to power data centers across these regions. Combined with nine solar and wind plants, AWS said it expects to generate more than 2.9 million megawatt hours of renewable energy a year.

To entice companies to switch to sustainable power, Iron Mountain in February launched a program to help its data-center users tally renewable-energy consumption, as a way to gauge progress on their own sustainability goals, often set by board-level mandates.

Mike Mattera, director of sustainability at Akamai Technologies Inc., said the program played a large part in the company’s decision to rent data-center space at Iron Mountain’s facility in New Jersey—with operations expected to go online within the next few weeks.

“This is really the first project where we can leverage documentation that can be used for renewable-energy credits,” Mr. Mattera said. “You’re definitely seeing more companies looking for those benefits,” he said.
